description: Miracle Park is a vibrant open-air attraction located on the last stretch of Batumi's Seafront Boulevard along Georgia's Black Sea coast. The park earned its name from the surprisingly rapid completion of its construction. It serves as a showcase of modern architecture and contemporary sculptures, blending historical landmarks like the 19th-century lighthouse with cutting-edge artistic installations. The park has become a central hub for cultural events, festivals, and leisure activities, offering visitors a unique blend of art, entertainment, and coastal atmosphere.
highlights: Ali and Nino Statue: An iconic 8-meter moving iron sculpture depicting a touching love story between an Azerbaijani youth and Georgian princess. The figures move toward each other, merge into one, pass through each other, and separate every 10 minutes, creating a mesmerizing display especially beautiful at night with colorful lighting effects

Alphabet Tower (Anbani Tower): A striking 130-meter tall structure combining the design of a DNA double helix with all 33 letters of the Georgian alphabet. Visitors can ascend the tower for panoramic views of Batumi and the Black Sea coastline
Chacha Tower: A 25-meter clock tower that dispenses Georgia's traditional grape brandy (chacha) from four stations every day at 7 PM for ten minutes - a unique and popular attraction for visitors

Historic Batumi Lighthouse: A 21-meter stone lighthouse built by French engineers in 1882, one of the last remaining relics of Batumi's history in an area dominated by modern development. A lighthouse has stood at this location since 1863 during Ottoman rule
Ferris Wheel: A 55-meter observation wheel offering fantastic panoramic views of the beaches, city, and coastline. Tickets cost approximately 3 GEL (less than $1.50 USD)

Modern Sculpture Collection: Features numerous contemporary art installations including 'Woman on a Bicycle', 'Sculpture in Love', 'Me, You and Batumi', 'Dolphins', 'Venus with Angels', 'Butterfly', 'Declaration of Love', 'Upside Down Boy', 'Snail', 'Inspiration', and 'Seedlings'
Cultural Events: During tourist season, the park hosts various concerts, electronic music festivals in summer, and special decorations during New Year celebrations
tips: Visit at night for the best experience - the park comes alive with illuminated sculptures and crowds, while daytime can be hot and less atmospheric
Don't miss the Ali and Nino sculpture's movement cycle every 10 minutes - the nighttime light show is particularly spectacular
Arrive at 7 PM to witness (and taste) the free chacha dispensing from the Chacha Tower - it's a fun local tradition
The park is open 24/7 with no entry fee, though individual attractions like the Ferris Wheel (3 GEL) and Alphabet Tower may have separate charges
Best visited from May to October when weather is pleasant for outdoor activities and most festivals occur
Great for cycling - explore the park quickly before joining the Batumi Boulevard bicycle path that extends along the coast
Plan to spend 1-2 hours exploring all the sculptures and attractions, or longer if attending an event
Easily accessible from Batumi Central Bus Station - approximately 30-minute walk along the boulevard or short taxi ride (5-10 GEL)
Combine your visit with a stroll along the entire Batumi Boulevard for a full coastal experience
Check local event schedules as the park frequently hosts concerts and festivals, especially during summer months
vibe: Contemporary and vibrant with a blend of artistic innovation and cultural tradition. Miracle Park offers an energetic, family-friendly atmosphere that comes alive especially in the evenings with illuminated sculptures and gathering crowds. The park successfully merges modern art installations with historical elements, creating a dynamic space where locals and tourists mingle. The coastal Black Sea setting adds a relaxed, breezy ambiance, while the eclectic mix of moving sculptures, entertainment options, and cultural events gives the park a lively, festival-like feel. It's both a contemplative space for art appreciation and an active social hub, embodying Batumi's transformation into a modern tourist destination while maintaining Georgian cultural touches like the chacha tradition.
